channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: With Western Weapons, Ukraine Is Turning the Tables in an Artillery War
item.description: In the southern Kherson region, Ukraine now has the advantage in range and precision guidance of artillery, rockets and drones, erasing what had been a critical Russian asset.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A team of Ukrainian soldiers armed a drone with bombs on Friday during a mission that destroyed a Russian armored personnel carrier on the front lines in the country’s southern Kherson region.

item.title: In Russia, Memorial Forced to Downsize Tribute to Stalin Victims
item.description: Memorial typically conducts a marathon reading of the names, ages, professions and dates of death of those killed under Stalin, but it had to find other ways to honor the victims after the authorities banned it.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: Twitter, Once a Threat to Titans, Now Belongs to One
item.description: A decade ago, the social media platform was a tool for rebels and those challenging authority. But over time, the powerful learned how to use it for their own goals.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Pablo Delcan

item.title: Elon Musk Starts Putting His Imprint on Twitter
item.description: The billionaire began as Twitter’s new owner by announcing a content moderation council and meeting employees, as some of the social media service’s users celebrated.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Lauren Hirsch and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Odd Andersen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Elon Musk closed his $44 billion deal to buy the social media service on Thursday night.

item.title: Pelosi’s Husband Is Gravely Injured in Hammer Attack by an Intruder
item.description: As leaders from across the political spectrum rushed to condemn the attack, Paul Pelosi underwent surgery to repair a skull fracture.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning, Tim Arango, Luke Broadwater and Holly Secon
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police and investigators at Speaker Nancy Pelosi's San Francisco residence, where her husband, Paul Pelosi, was attacked by an intruder early Friday morning.

item.title: Pelosi Attack Highlights Rising Fears of Political Violence
item.description: The assault of the House speaker’s husband inside their home comes as threats against members of Congress have increased in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Andrew Harnik/Associated Press
item.media:description: Security personnel standing guard while Representative Steve Scalise, Republican of Louisiana, was speaking on the steps of the Capitol last year. Mr. Scalise was shot in 2017 by a man with a grudge against Republicans.

item.title: Attack on Nancy Pelosi’s Husband, Paul Pelosi: What We Know
item.description: Paul Pelosi, 82, underwent surgery for a skull fracture after he was assaulted at the couple’s home in San Francisco, and was expected to recover, a spokesman for Ms. Pelosi said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Biden’s Agenda Hangs in the Balance if Republicans Take Congress
item.description: On a wide array of issues like abortion, taxes, race and judges, President Biden’s opportunities would shrink as Republicans vow to dismantle much of his legislative accomplishments.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: If Republicans capture one or both houses of Congress in midterm elections, President Biden will be forced to defend the legislative accomplishments of his first two years in office.

item.title: In Ohio, G.O.P. Sees a Clean Victory as Democrats Predict an Upset
item.description: Polls show Representative Tim Ryan competing within the margin of error against his Republican opponent, J.D. Vance, in the high-profile Ohio Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Ryan speaking to supporters at the United Auto Workers’ Local 14 in Toledo, Ohio.

item.title: What to Know About New York’s Midterm Elections
item.description: The state has become a bellwether for both parties, with significant congressional seats in play and an increasingly close governor’s race.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting in New York begins on Saturday, Oct. 29, and ends Sunday, Nov. 6, two days before Election Day.

item.title: An ‘Army’ of Volunteer Sleuths Are Out Hunting for Your Stolen Car
item.description: In Portland, Ore., vehicle thefts have soared, and the police say they are focused on other crimes. Now victims are helping each other track down their own cars.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Justin Katigbak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Titan Crawford has led a growing network of volunteer sleuths who scour Portland’s streets, alleys and forests, racing against time in hopes of finding stolen vehicles before they end up shredded for parts.

item.title: Philadelphia’s Rob Thomson Makes the Right Calls in World Series Game 1
item.description: Determined to capitalize on his team’s momentum, Phillies Manager Rob Thomson went to his top relievers early in Game 1. The moves paid off with a win on the road.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Kepner
item.media:credit: Troy Taormina/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Manager Rob Thomson’s aggressive use of his bullpen paid off in Game 1 of the World Series.

item.title: World Series Game 1: JT Realmuto’s Homer Gives Phillies 10th Inning Win
item.description: Houston got off to an early 5-0 lead but watched it evaporate. Realmuto tied the game with a double in the fifth and put his team ahead to stay with a homer in the 10th.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.T. Realmuto went 2 for 4 with a home run and three R.B.I. in Philadelphia’s win over Houston in Game 1 of the World Series.

item.title: World Series: Nick Castellanos Saved Phillies With Catch in Game 1
item.description: A fly ball in the ninth inning could easily have been a winning hit for Houston, but Nick Castellanos made a long run and a sliding catch, just has he had done against Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Carmen Mandato/Getty Images
item.media:description: Nick Castellanos’s sliding catch in the ninth inning prevented Houston’s Jose Altuve from scoring what would have been the game-winning run on Friday.

item.title: Why Is New York Still Building on the Waterfront?
item.description: There are two simple reasons. One, it makes money. And two, people just love water.
item.dc:creator: Ginia Bellafante
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hurricane Sandy seems to have had little effect on demand for waterfront condominiums in the city.

item.title: Five Ways to Prevent the Next Sandy
item.description: When Hurricane Sandy deluged New York City, leaders promised bold action. Ten years later, it’s fair to ask: What, exactly, has been done?
item.dc:creator: Anne Barnard and Jade Doskow
item.media:credit: Jade Doskow for The New York Times

item.title: Hurricane Sandy, in Pictures
item.description: Ten years later, the photos are still here.
item.dc:creator: John Leland
item.media:credit: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of Sandy in Breezy Point, Queens.

item.title: A Timeline of Hurricane Sandy
item.description: From a single wave off the coast of Africa to a $52 billion sea wall a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hu and Patrick McGeehan
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victor Concepcion, a janitor who was mandated to stay the night at P.S. 8 in Dumbo in Brooklyn, surveys the arrival of Sandy.

item.title: Steve Keene Made 300,000 Paintings in a Home Full of Easels
item.description: The artist’s studio and living space, created with his wife, Starling Keene, an architect, houses a one-man assembly line of affordable art — enough to fill a new book.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steve Keene at home in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in a studio encircled in chain-link fencing that he affectionately calls “the cage.”

item.title: The Pelosis and a Haunted America
item.description: Gruesome Republicans are writing our national horror story.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Jim Gerberich/Associated Press
item.media:description: Nancy and Paul Pelosi in 1987. They have been married for 59 years.

item.title: Don’t Buy the Republican Appeal to Workers
item.description: For ordinary workers, living paycheck to paycheck, the G.O.P. is AWOL.
item.dc:creator: Terri Gerstein
item.media:credit: Brian Kaiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance, left, speaking at a Republican event this month.

item.title: Elon Musk Is Buying Twitter. Shudder.
item.description: Rogue billionaires have appeared before, and they will appear again. But this one will control our “digital town square.”
item.dc:creator: David Nasaw
item.media:credit: Andrew Kelly/Reuters

item.title: I’m No Longer Sure New York Will Protect Itself From Rising Waters
item.description: Given the funding gaps and ever-extending deadlines for flood protection measures, is it better to be realistic about Manhattan’s future?
item.dc:creator: Marco Pasanella
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marco Pasanella, owner of Pasanella & Son, Vintners, lost 10,000 bottles of wine in Hurricane Sandy in 2012.

item.title: Garden Varieties
item.description: Fall is well and truly here. It’s a good time to check in with your houseplants.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Political Power of Gas Prices and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images

item.title: It’s 2024. Trump Backers Won’t Certify the Election. What Next, Legally?
item.description: The question is most urgent in Arizona, where two of the former president’s loyalists may well become governor and secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Trump supporter outside the Arizona State Capitol in Phoenix in 2020, when the state became a hotbed of conspiracy theories about the presidential election.

item.title: Not the Daughter She Wanted
item.description: When it comes to whom she loves, an immigrant daughter can’t make her mother happy. But she holds on to hope, as her mother always taught her to do.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: At Least 2 Killed in a Halloween Crowd Surge in South Korea
item.description: Images showed firefighters carrying what looked like bodies covered with white sheets on stretchers to ambulances in the popular Itaewon neighborhood in Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jung Yeon-Je/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A person, believed to have suffered from cardiac arrest, is transported into an ambulance in the popular nightlife district of Itaewon in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Vince Dooley, Hall of Fame Football Coach for Georgia, Dies at 90
item.description: In a 25-year coaching career, he appeared in 20 bowl games and won 201 games, the fourth-highest total in Southeastern Conference history.
item.dc:creator: Frank Litsky
item.media:credit: Gene Blythe/Associated Press
item.media:description: Vince Dooley, the University of Georgia’s head coach, was carried off the field after Georgia defeated Notre Dame, 17-10, in the Sugar Bowl on Jan. 1, 1981.

item.title: Sacheen Littlefeather and the Question of Native Identity
item.description: The actress, who died Oct. 2, became famous for a protest at the 1973 Oscars. Now a researcher and Littlefeather’s own sisters dispute her claims that she was Native American. Her defenders say Indian identity is a complex matter.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Michael Levenson
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:credit: Frazer Harrison/Getty Images
item.media:description: Sacheen Littlefeather at an event in September in her honor at the Academy Museum in Los Angeles. She was joined by Bird Runningwater, the co-chairman of the Academy’s Indigenous Alliance.

item.title: After the Floods, Eastern Kentucky Ponders What Was Lost
item.description: With hundreds of houses damaged or even washed away, a question looms in parts of the region: How many families who persevered there for generations will now leave for good?
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson and Jared Hamilton
item.media:credit: Jared Hamilton for The New York Times

item.title: How to Help Someone With Depression
item.description: Whether they are coping with seasonal symptoms or chronic depression, here’s how to offer love and understanding while still caring for yourself.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Francesco Ciccolella

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón

item.title: Terrence Real’s Latest Book Explores Fixing What Ails Us
item.description: In his new book, ‘Us’, Terrence Real explores how ‘enlightened self interest’ could save your relationship.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Jones
item.media:credit: Seb Agresti

item.title: How Online Dating Apps Can Lead to Burnout
item.description: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Max Guther

item.title: ‘Sherman’s Showcase’ Is Back, Silly Smarts Intact
item.description: Spaceship? Check. Trap nursery rhymes? Check. Dashikis? Check. After a long pandemic hiatus, this musical comedy tribute to Black culture has returned, as joyfully absurd as ever.
item.dc:creator: Leigh-Ann Jackson
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bashir Salahuddin, as Sherman McDaniels, during filming for the second season of “Sherman’s Showcase.” The musical spoof is returning to TV more than three years after it debuted.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
